title: Understanding expressions
text:
In order to understand expressions, we have to break the expression down into its terms. A term is a group of constants (numbers) and variables (like \(x\)) combined together with various operators like \(\times\) and \(\div\). Terms are separated by binary operators \(+\) and \(-\). Here are a few examples of terms and non-terms.
Terms
\(4x\)
\(12\)
\(y^2\)
\(\frac{7}{12}\)
Not Terms
\(4 + x\)
\(6 - k\)
\((6 - x)x^2\)
\((x-2)(x+2)\)

title: Examples of expressions
text:
Let's build an expression from the examples above. All we have to do is combine the terms using \(+\) and/or \(-\) $$4x + 12 + y^2 - \frac{7}{12}$$ Easy right ? Here are a few more examples of expressions.
\(x^2 - x + 1\)
\(xy - x + 5\)
\(0 + 23\)

title: Evaluating Expressions
text:
Now for the fun part. For completeness, we are going to evaluate two different kinds of expressions.

Let's start with an expression without variables.
$$5 + 4\times 2^3 - 1$$
When evaluating an expression with no variables, we can simply evaluate by applying BEDMAS.

$$\begin{aligned}
5 + 4\times 2^3 - 1 &= 5 + 4\times 2^3 - 1 &&\text{Exponent}\\
&= 5 + 4\times 8 - 1 &&\text{Multiplication}\\
&= 5 + 32 - 1 &&\text{Addition}\\
&= 37 - 1 &&\text{Subtraction}\\
&= 36 &&\text{$\square$}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Good stuff. Now let's evaluate an expression with variables.

$$\begin{aligned}
x^2 - 5x + 8 &&\text{at $x = 3$}\\
\end{aligned}$$

We have to perform an additional step at the start before we can evaluate, which is to substitute the value given for the variable, in this case \(3\) for \(x\). 

Then evaluate like a simple expression by applying BEDMAS.

$$\begin{aligned}
x^2 - 5x + 8 &= (3)^2 - 5(3) + 8 && \text{substitute in 3 wherever you see $x$}\\
&= 3^2 - 5 \times 3 + 8 &&\text{Exponent}\\
&= 9 - 5 \times 3 + 8 &&\text{Multiplication}\\
&= 9 - 15 + 8 &&\text{Subtraction (since it comes before Addition)}\\
&= -6 + 8 &&\text{Addition}\\
&= 2 &&\text{$\square$}\\
\end{aligned}$$

That's it! Now you know how to evaluate an expression. Practice these concepts in the Exercise section below.
